webTitle: Aldi to introduce 'healthier tills' at all 500 of its UK stores by January 2015

fields.bodyText: The discount grocer Aldi has become the latest supermarket to introduce "healthier tills" at all of its stores across the UK, though the change will not happen until January 2015. All confectionery, chocolate and sweets will be removed from stands at Aldi's checkouts and replaced with healthier options including dried fruit, nuts, juices and water. The move follows a 16-week trial in a selected number of Aldi's 500 UK stores which ran from February to June this year. Giles Hurley, joint managing director of corporate buying at the supermarket, said: "The healthier tills trial quickly showed that healthier foods prove more popular with our shoppers than the traditional checkout offer of confectionery and sweets." The UK's largest retailer, Tesco, announced in May that it was to ban sweets and chocolates from its checkouts after a survey of customers showed overwhelming support for the move. In January, Aldi's German discount competitor, Lidl, banned confectionery from the checkout at all 600 of its British stores after a survey of parents' views. It replaced racks of sweets at the tills with dried and fresh fruit, oatcakes and juices. Richard Lloyd, executive director of the consumer group Which?, said: "It is welcome news that Aldi is promoting healthier tills across all of its stores. We want all retailers to ensure that product positioning, particularly at the checkout, helps people to make healthier choices."

webTitle: Hewlett-Packard to sue UK arm of auditor firm Deloitte

fields.bodyText: Hewlett-Packard has revealed it plans to sue the UK arm of Deloitte, auditor of the Cambridge software firm Autonomy that HP bought for $11bn (£6.6bn) before writing off nearly half the company's value and accusing the former management of accounting improprieties. The latest threat came as a San Francisco judge shot down HP's $48m settlement with two law firms which had been pursuing HP directors over the affair on behalf of disgruntled shareholders. HP instead had persuaded the firms to drop the class action and join it in pursuing Autonomy's former management. HP bought Autonomy in 2011 but the following year wrote down its value by $5bn, blaming "accounting improprieties, misrepresentation and disclosure failures" by its former management. The Californian laptops, printers, servers and software group's shares crashed after the announcement. HP has repeatedly threatened court action against Autonomy founder Mike Lynch and his finance director Sushovan Hussain. On Monday, during the hearing over HP's settlement with shareholders, the company's lawyer Marc Wolinsky disclosed that HP also planned to sue Deloitte over its auditing of the Autonomy accounts. An HP spokesperson said: "We will continue to work to have the derivative actions settled or dismissed and to hold the former executives of Autonomy as well as Autonomy's auditor, Deloitte UK, responsible for the wrongdoing that occurred." Deloitte signed off Autonomy's accounts in 2009 and 2010, a period during which HP claims to have found a number of irregularities. HP claims that more than $200m of Autonomy's $1bn revenues in 2010 were questionable. A spokesperson for Deloitte UK countered: "Any possible claim would be utterly without merit and we will defend ourselves strongly against it. Deloitte was not engaged by HP, or by Autonomy, to provide any due diligence in relation to the acquisition of Autonomy. Deloitte UK was auditor to Autonomy at the time of its acquisition by HP. Deloitte UK conducted its audit work in full compliance with regulation and professional standards." This week the Guardian revealed Deloitte was aware of the details of three transactions which HP says cast doubt over Autonomy's dealings with resellers – companies selling its software on to end users. Kraft, Eli Lilly and KMPG were named as end users of Autonomy software in multimillion-dollar deals with resellers, sales which helped boost Autonomy's quarterly revenues. All three deals were subsequently restructured, with one reseller paid $400,000 in compensation fees. Lynch and Hussain deny all allegations of wrongdoing and blame the writedown in their company's value on bad management by HP. The HP allegations have prompted an investigation by the US Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Bureau of Investigation, as well as the UK's Serious Fraud Office. At the San Francisco hearing, called to give preliminary approval to HP's settlement of shareholder class actions, US district judge Charles Breyer rejected the fees attorneys would have recouped under the settlement. "That's out," he said. HP had promised Cotchett, Pitre & McCarthly and Robbins Geller Rudman & Dowd $18m in over 32 months, so long as they switched their efforts to pursuing Lynch and Hussain. Should legal action against the former Autonomy managers be successful, the firms could win a further maximum of $30m. It is understood both firms have already agreed to sign the settlement without the promise of fees. A number of parties objected to the shareholder settlement, including Hussain. In court on Monday, Hussain's attorney John Keker called the deal a "whitewash". "This is a joke," Keker said. "If it were a carcass, animals would walk around it, it stinks so much." Marc Wolinsky, HP's lawyer, said HP would vigorously contest Hussain's ability to review documents. Breyer has scheduled a hearing for 26 September. The judge said he would need to weigh the evidence against HP officers as part of his analysis on whether the deal absolving them of liability is fair for shareholders. "Something went terribly wrong," Breyer said of the Autonomy acquisition.

webTitle: Burger King acquires Tim Hortons and calls Obama's bluff over tax

fields.bodyText: Wall Street’s dealmakers called Barack Obama’s bluff on Tuesday with the acquisition by Burger King of a Canadian coffee chain, which could embolden other multinationals looking for similar tax savings to move their headquarters abroad. Though faced with vocal opposition from the White House to the process known as tax inversions, the bankers and lawyers advising Burger King will have known that the president has a weak hand: without binding legislation from Congress to close the underlying tax loophole that allows such deals, the president had limited options beyond naming and shaming those who exploit it. Until now, this threat of moral opprobrium in Washington and theoretical risk of future legislation that might require reversing the transaction have been enough to deter several previous attempts. Drug store chain Walgreens abandoned similar plans to move its US headquarters to Europe when it bought the remainder of Alliance Boots. Pfizer had been examining a similar move as part of its initially-rebuffed approach to AstraZeneca. But with many multinationals accumulating growing piles of cash in overseas subsidiaries that they are reluctant to repatriate to high tax jurisdictions like the US, there is growing pressure to structure mergers in ways that allow the whole corporate entity to move to a cheaper location. That the Burger King and Tim Hortons deal was partially funded by Warren Buffett, a billionaire previously noted for criticising the low tax rates enjoyed by the very rich, only served to underscore a view on Wall Street that it is up to lawmakers to change the law if they don’t like its consequences. Such arrangements have already proven popular elsewhere this year. Among proposed US cross-border mergers, nearly two-thirds are being done for the tax benefit, according to data from Thomson Reuters. Tax inversions, newly popularized by the law firm Skadden Arps Meagher & Flom four years ago, have taken on a new popularity this year as many corporations struggle to appease shareholders looking askance at growing corporate cash piles. While corporate cash piles act as a bulwark during recessionary times, the recovering economy has made the multibillion-dollar cash hoards look like bad financial management. Many US corporations have complained loudly about US tax rates, even though it’s rare that they pay the full burden of 35% to 39%. Out of the Fortune 500 of prominent US companies, 288 paid an effective US federal tax rate of just 19.4% between 2008 and 2012, according to advocacy group Citizens for Tax Justice. The conflict really centres around the profits that US companies generate overseas. These foreign profits have flooded the coffers of US companies, making up the bulk of an estimated $1.5 trillion in excess cash. Some, like Apple, have burned down some of the money by returning it to shareholders in the form of dividends, or have bought back their own stock in an attempt to drive their share prices higher on the open market. Still, the trillions remain out of reach until the companies make peace with the taxes they will have to pay, and Apple CEO Tim Cook has testified to federal officials in favor of a tax holiday. Until that is resolved, inversions continue. Earlier this year, US healthcare company Medtronic merged with Ireland’s Covidian in a tax inversion which drew little outrage. As more high-profile companies including Walgreen have flirted with the idea, however, the White House has demonstrated its displeasure. Burger King and Tim Hortons, perhaps seeking to avoid the wrath of Washington, played down the tax benefits in several conference calls with media and investors. Executives said the merger has no tax benefit, and Burger King also said that its current tax rate in the mid-20% range is comparable to the Canadian tax rate. Still, Burger King and Tim Hortons may protest too much. The US Treasury is already on alert from previous deals, and this pairing is a tasty morsel for federal officials who may wish to make an example of a prominent inversion deal. The merger “is likely to add fuel to the fire around tax inversions,” wrote Keith Moore, the founder of Wall Street trading-research firm MKM Partners. “With the US Treasury examining ways to curb inversions without specific legislation, this transaction could add to pressure to seek ways to discourage the strategy.” The tension that has already built around inversions is likely to push the issue to a head in Congress, even in the expected doldrums of an election year. The US Treasury, which controls the Internal Revenue Service, initially said it couldn’t stop the inversions on its own. More recently, Jack Lew said the Treasury was examining “possible administrative actions that could limit the ability of companies to engage in inversions.”

webTitle: RBS to be fined £15m for giving poor sales advice to mortgage customers

fields.standfirst: Latest penalty takes bank's fines for the year to around £265m
fields.body:
The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) will fine Royal Bank of Scotland about £15m for giving poor sales advice to mortgage customers in the latest blow to the taxpayer-controlled bank's reputation.

RBS's chief executive, Ross McEwan, has promised to clean up RBS after it was hit by a series of big fines across its businesses. The fine relates to UK customers.

McEwan has said RBS needs to regain the trust of its customers if it is to turn itself around after six years of scandals and dire financial performance, and has admitted the bank's mortgage advisers needed better training.

The bank has been fined hundreds of millions of pounds by UK and international regulators since it was rescued by the taxpayer in 2008. Past penalties include £390m for rigging the benchmark Libor rate and £8.75m for breaches of money-laundering rules by its Coutts business. RBS has also set aside £3.2bn for misselling customers payment protection insurance.

RBS is under investigation, along with other banks, in connection with alleged collusion in the foreign exchange market. It is also waiting for a big fine from the FCA over the breakdown of its computer systems in 2012.

McEwan joined RBS that year to lead its retail bank and took over as group chief executive in October last year to replace Stephen Hester, who was ousted by the chancellor, George Osborne. McEwan and his chairman, Sir Philip Hampton, have said the threat of litigation and regulatory action is the biggest obstacle to the government starting to sell the 81% stake in RBS acquired when the taxpayer bailed the bank out at the height of the financial crisis.

The punishment for RBS will take the FCA's fines this year to about £265m. The regulator doled out £136m in penalties in the first half of this year, suggesting a slowdown from last year's record £474m. But last month's £105m fine for Lloyds Banking Group put it on track for another bumper year.

RBS and the FCA declined to comment on the fine, which is due to be announced on Wednesday morning.

webTitle: Scottish yes vote and British EU exit could hit UK economy, says Sorrell

fields.bodyText: WPP boss Sir Martin Sorrell has warned that the prospect of Scotland voting for independence and Britain leaving the European Union could weaken the UK economy, adding to worries over heightened geopolitical tensions in Ukraine and the Middle East. The chief executive of the world's biggest advertising company said there was "everything to play for" before next month's Scottish independence referendum after Alex Salmond was widely seen to have won Monday's second televised debate. Polling by one of WPP's businesses has put the no campaign ahead, but the number of undecided voters is greater than the gap between the two sides, Sorrell said. "It heightens the level of uncertainty, so it's not good. There is a vote and we don't know what the result is going to be. Whether it's a yes or a no, any business is having to think about what the implications of yes are." Even if Scotland voted to stay in the union, there might be further uncertainty for businesses if a strong yes vote led to calls for greater devolution from Westminster, Sorrell said. "If it is very close, which it may be, they will say a lot of people voted yes and there will be devo max." The Guardian's snap poll of Scottish voters found that 71% believed Salmond, the Scottish National party leader, won his second debate with Alistair Darling, who heads the Better Together campaign. Darling had edged ahead in the first debate by concentrating on Salmond's lack of answers on the future of Scotland's currency, but failed to repeat the damage on Monday. Business leaders including HSBC's Scottish-born chairman, Douglas Flint, have warned that a vote for independence could damage Scotland's economy and reduce investment in the country. Sorrell said that with the general election nine months away, businesses were also worried about the UK leaving the EU, after David Cameron promised a referendum in 2017 if the Conservatives formed the next government. "One thing to think about is what will happen if the Conservatives win the election or, as is more likely, they are the biggest party. It's very difficult for businesses to come to that view. It might affect the way they think about investing in the UK or what they do in the UK. It increases the level of uncertainty, which is not helpful." Sorrell said concerns over Scottish independence and EU membership came close to adding two more items to his existing list of four geopolitical "known unknowns" – where the problem is known but the outcome is in doubt: the fragility of the eurozone, tension in the Middle East, the fate of the Chinese economy and resolving the US deficit. With political tensions high in many international troublespots, the UK could do without self-created uncertainties, he said. A year ago, the eurozone was the biggest fear for business leaders, but at meetings with other business leaders, Sorrell said, he found events in Ukraine and the Middle East were now the leading concern. "It [the eurozone] has been replaced by Russia and the Middle East, and in particular by Russia and the impact of sanctions. "I was somewhat surprised, but people are really worried about the impact of sanctions spreading. Germany and other countries that trade with Russia are not going to be able to do that." Sorrell said that though clients were more confident than at the height of the financial crisis in 2008, the intensity of international political turmoil made them unwilling to take risks and invest. Instead, they were cutting costs and looking to mergers and acquisitions for growth. "There are a lot of flashpoints. There seems to be more turmoil than for a long period, sadly. When you think about it that way, that is why people are so worried." WPP's businesses span advertising, marketing, PR and data analysis in more than 100 countries. In the first half of this year, the company's results were ravaged by the strength of the pound, Sorrell said. Revenues increased 2.7% to £5.47bn, but were up 11.3% excluding currency movements. The UK was WPP's strongest market for underlying sales, rising 19.2% against 11.9% in Asia and other emerging markets. Despite his concerns about a referendum on EU membership, Sorrell said the chancellor, George Osborne, had done a good job to get the economy growing by keeping government spending under control.

webTitle: A French history lesson: Hollande needed a Marshall Plan for Europe | Larry Elliott

fields.bodyText: It was late April 2017 when the penny finally dropped in Berlin. Until then, the assumption in Germany had been that despite 10 years of virtual stagnation and unemployment at 14%, one of the mainstream parties would emerge victorious in the French presidential elections due the following month. Yet, with the campaign in its final stages, opinion polls suggested Marine Le Pen, leader of the extreme rightwing Front National, was on course to become the next president of France. Le Pen's message was simple. France should leave the euro, run its own economic policy along protectionist lines and have a blanket ban on immigration. How did it come to this? For the past five years, ever since the election of François Hollande as socialist president in 2012, Germany had called the shots in Europe. webTitle: Martin Sorrell warns on Scottish independence; Backlash over Burger King takeover

The day’s events:

  • Afternoon summary
  • Burger King’s takeover of Tim Hortons upsets some US customers
  • Sorrell: Scottish referendum increases uncertainty
  • ...and Russia has replaced eurozone as main risk
  • US consumer confidence hits record high
  • Morning summary: City cheered by prospect of eurozone QE
  • Shares up, eurozone bond yields down
fields.body:
5.06pm BST

European markets close higher

The prospect of stimulus measures such as QE by the European Central Bank, as floated by Mario Draghi in the US on Friday, has continued to support markets. European markets recovered ground after an early dip while the FTSE 100 played catch up after Monday’s Bank Holiday to reach a seven week high (details in Nick Fletcher’s closing market report). Sentiment was also helped by better than expected US consumer confidence and durable goods figures, while the collapse of the French government caused few ripples. Hopes of easing tensions in the Ukraine as well as Gaza was the icing on the cake. So the closing scores showed:

  • The FTSE 100 finished up 47.76 points or 0.7% at 6822.76
  • Germany’s Dax rose 0.82% to 9588.15
  • France’s Cac closed 1.18% better at 4393.41
  • Italy’s FTSE MIB added 1.33% to 20,645.54
  • Spain’s Ibex ended 1.28% higher at 10,826.9

On Wall Street the Dow Jones Industrial Average is currently 0.34% or 57 points higher while the S&P 500 has hit yet another new high of 2003.

On that note, it’s time to close up for the evening. Thanks for all your comments and we’ll be back again tomorrow.

Updated at 5.07pm BST

4.01pm BST

Afternoon summary

Time to recap, I think...

One of Britain’s top businesspeople has warned that the Scottish independence vote, and the upcoming UK referendum on European Union membership, are “grey swan” risks to the recovery.

Sir Martin Sorrell argued this morning that:

There is all to play for as we go into the election.

Obviously it does increase uncertainty in the UK, it’s not good.

[the question of] “What is our position in relation to the European market, to the EU?” is an added uncertainty.

Sorrell also declared that geopolitical tensions in Russia, and the Middle East, has elbowed the eurozone down the list of biggest worries for business leaders.

The eurozone was the big topic of conversation and concern this time last year.

This year it’s been replaced by the Middle East, and in particular by Russia and the impact of sanctions.

US consumers don’t appear to be too concerned. Consumer confidence has hit its highest level since October 2007, the autumn of the credit crunch.

Burger King has confirmed that it is acquiring Canadian coffee chain Tim Hortons in an $11bn deal. Full story here.

The move has prompted a backlash from some customers, who fear Burger King will use the acquisition to cut its tax bill.

The other economic news from America is more mixed. Orders for durable goods have risen at a record rate, thanks to sales of aircraft.

But house price growth is stalling.

The prospect of the European Central Bank announcing new stimulus measures, such as a quantitative easing programme, send shares rallying in London today. The FTSE 100 is up 40 points, or 0.6%, in late trading. The French and German markets are also up again, adding to Monday’s gains.

Bond prices also strengthened, pushing yields on German, Spanish and Italian sovereign debt even lower.

While in Greece, a new ‘code of ethics’ has been agreed to tackle its mountain of bad debts.

The OECD has reported that advanced economies grew by just 0.4% in the second quarter of 2014, led by the US and UK.

3.29pm BST

Burger King backlash

Burger King’s decision to buy Canada’s Tim Hortons for $11.4bn has gone down badly with some customers, who are unhappy that the fast food chain could shift its tax base to Canada.

Thanks to the magic of social media, you can see the outrage unfolding on Burger King’s Facebook page.

This post summed up the mood:

I pay my taxes and expect companies to do the same. If BK leaves the us to avoid taxes then I will never spend another dollar there!

Senator Sherrod Brown has already suggested that customers should boycott Burger King if it inverts its tax base.

One Facebooker wants the Senate to go further:

As a veteran I encourage you to sponsor a bill that shuts down every single Burger King located on an American military installation in the U.S...

Burger King management, meanwhile, insist that they’re not being driven by the prospect of lower tax bills (perish the very thought, children)

That may not quieten these critics:

Updated at 3.30pm BST

3.13pm BST

US consumer confidence hits highest level since October 2007

US consumer morale has surged to its highest level since the early days of the financial crisis.

The monthly survey of US consumer confidence has just smashed expectations by jumping to 92.4 for August. That’s the highest reading since October 2007, up from 90.3 in July, according to the Confidence Board’s report.

The report includes signs that the labor market picked up this month, with people reporting it was easier to find new jobs.

Some caution is needed, though - other consumer confidence surveys have been less bullish recently, as this chart shows:

Updated at 3.13pm BST

2.47pm BST

Capital Economics aren’t getting carried away by the surge in US durable goods orders, thanks to that spike in aircraft sales.

They caution:

July’s spectacular durable goods orders provide a misleadingly strong signal on the strength of the economy, although the outlook for business investment is improving.

2.46pm BST

2.39pm BST

And here’s the details of the latest US housing data, showing that seasonally adjusted prices fell in several cities including Detroit, Minneapolis and San Francisco.

2.25pm BST

US house prices fall

The latest survey of US house prices has just hit the wires, and shows an unexpected dip in prices in June - suggesting the market may be losing steam.

The S&P/Case Shiller index of 20 metropolitan areas showed the average family home price fell 0.2% month-on-month, seasonally adjusted. Economists had expected a flat reading.

On an unadjusted basis, prices at these 20 areas rose by 1%.

Nationally, prices fell by 0.1% on a seasonally adjusted basis. Year-on-year, prices are up by 6.2% across America, but there are signs that the rally is petering out, as the US Federal Reserve moves closer to normalising monetary policy.

S&P Dow Jones Indices, which compiles the report, says it shows “a sustained slowdown in price increases.”

David Blitzer, chairman of the Index Committee at S&P Dow Jones Indices, explains:

“Home price gains continue to ease as they have since last fall.

The monthly National Index rose 0.9% in June. While all 20 cities saw higher home prices over the last 12 months, all experienced slower gains. In San Francisco, the pace of price increases halved since late last summer.

The Sun Belt cities – Las Vegas, Phoenix, Miami and Tampa – all remain a third or more below their peak prices set almost a decade ago.”

In contrast, the average UK house price is now above its pre-crisis peak.

Blitzer warns that the prospect of rising US interest rates will weigh on the market:

“Bargain basement mortgage rates won’t continue forever; recent improvements in the labor markets and comments from Fed chair Janet Yellen and others hint that interest rates could rise as soon as the first quarter of 2015. Rising mortgage rates won’t send housing into a tailspin, but will further dampen price gains.”

1.44pm BST

The record-breaking durable goods survey also shows a 318% spike in demand for civilian planes.

So why did aircraft orders shoot up so much last month? Well, as fastFT points out, July was the month of the Farnborough Airshow.

The diplomatic spat between Russia and the UK, which saw its delegation recalled home, dominated attention. But behind the scenes, US aerospace firms must have been racking up the orders.

1.37pm BST

US durable goods orders rise by record 22.6%

Just in: orders for US durable goods have soared by a record amount, and it’s all thanks to increased demand for aircraft.

Durable goods orders surged by 22.6% in July, smashing expectations of a 7.5% rise.

Strip out transportation orders, though, and orders for durable goods (items designed to last at least three years) fell by 0.8%.

June’s durable goods report has been revised higher, to +2.7% from +0.7% originally.

Updated at 1.37pm BST

1.22pm BST

A handy comparison:

1.13pm BST

The Burger King deal values Tim Hortons at C$12.5bn, or almost £7bn, btw.

1.03pm BST

Burger King seals deal to buy Tim Hortons

It’s official: US fast food chain Burger King is merging with Canadian coffee and doughnut chain Tim Hortons.

The deal will create the world’s third-largest “quick service” restaurant company, more than 18,000 restaurants turning over a whopping $23bn of sales.

The two companies will maintain the current “global homes” in Oakville and Miami respectively once the deal goes though.

The merger is controversial, though -- it could allow Burger King cut its tax bills by shifting its tax domicile to Canada, where corporation tax is lower.

Burger King’s majority owners, 3G Capital, have agreed to pay $94.05 Canadian dollars per share for Tim Hortons, in cash and shares.

Tim Hortons shares were worth around C$67 last week, before news of a possible deal broke.

Warren Buffett has a part to play in the deal too -- his Berkshire Hathaway investment group is providing $3bn of financing.

And Tim Hortons has reassured staff that there will be no changes to ‘restaurant level’ employment.

Updated at 1.05pm BST

12.41pm BST

UK housing market in focus

There’s a flurry of new data on the UK housing market today.

First up, the number of new mortgages approved by lenders dipped last month to 42,792, below the recent average.

But the average loan value increased, from £163,800 in June to £167,600 in July - as prices kept rising.

More here: Small dip in July mortgage approvals offset by increase in average value

Secondly, estate agent Savills has revised up its forecasts for price growth.

It now expects average annual UK house price growth of 9.5% this year, ahead of the 6.5% originally forecast.

Savills also acknowledged that London’s property boom has taken it by surprise. It originally expected price growth of 8.5% this year - now upgraded to 15%.

But over the next five years, average UK prices should slightly outpace the capital, it reckons, growing by 25%:

12.05pm BST

Irish jobless rate drops to 11.5%

Ireland’s unemployment rate has hit its lowest level since the financial crisis struck the Celtic Tiger, as more people find work, and more people left the labour force altogether.

The jobless rate across the Republic fell to 11.5% in the April-June quarter, the Central Statistics Office reported.

Employment is up by 1.7% over the last year, with 31,600 more people finding work. And the number of unemployed people dropped by 46,200, taking the total to 254,500.

The total labour force has contracted too, by 14,500.

11.36am BST

Another chart from the OECD, showing how the UK and US economies outpaced the major economies in the last quarter:

Updated at 11.54am BST

11.23am BST

11.21am BST

OECD: Advanced economies grew 0.4% in last quarter

Growth has picked up in the world’s major developed economies, with the UK and US making up for the weakness of Japan and the eurozone.

That’s according to a new report from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development reports. It says GDP across the 33 countries who make up the OECD area rose by 0.4% in April-June, up from 0.2% in January-March.

There was “a wide spectrum of patterns across countries”, though. Real quarterly growth in the US surged by 1%, followed by Britain with 0.8%.

Japan contracted by 1.7% as a new sales tax hit spending, Germany shrank by 0.2% and France was flat.

10.49am BST

South Africa avoids recession

South Africa’s economy has returned to growth, avoiding a new recession, but not expanding as fast as hoped.

Statistics South Africa reports that the country’s GDP rose by 0.6% in the second quarter of 2014, reversing the 0.6% contraction recorded in January-March. Economists had predicted growth of 0.9%.

On an annual basis, GDP is up by 1%, compared to 1.6% in the previous quarter, indicating a slowdown.

10.34am BST

Greece agrees new ethics code for bad bank loans

Over to Greece where the debt-stricken country’s central bank has devised a new “code of ethics” to deal with the ever worsening problem of non performing loans.

Our correspondent Helena Smith reports from Athens:

It’s a problem that has mirrored Greece’s seemingly never ending debt crisis: the issue of non performing loans. With some 35% of all lender loans no longer being serviced, the country’s central bank reckons that an estimated €75bn in total is currently owed to banks, among the largest amounts in global financial history and for a nation off just over 11 million proportionately by far the largest in the EU.

“It’s the biggest headache for our banking system and a major drain on our ability to provide credit,” said one banker requesting anonymity. “The new code has been a priority over the summer.”

Ahead of EU-wide stress tests in October, Greece’s central bank has now devised a new code (yet to be fine-tuned) that reportedly allows ‘compromise solutions’ to be found for lenders and debtors.

Rubber-stamped by the Committee of Credit and Insurance Matters on Monday the code, say insiders, foresees “haircuts” being extended to loans, revisions on interest repayments, the conversion of mortgages into rental contracts and the voluntary return of properties to banks (a way for lenders not to be seen to be forcibly requisitioning assets). Foreclosures will be activated if mortgage borrowers are seen to be deliberately uncooperative - with the collapse of property prices many Greeks, hit by austerity measures, simply gave up on repayments as the crisis intensified.

“Such steps have been taken in other [EU] countries to handle non performing loans. Frankly we’ve dragged our feet. It’s in no one’s interest to have this hanging,” said the banker. “All round this should be a relief.”

Former finance minister Yannis Stournaras who assumed the post of governor of the bank of Greece earlier this summer, is believed to be pushing hard for the code of ethics to be applied before the stress tests later this year.

Bankers have not hidden their concerns that Greek lenders may need big capital injections to survive (despite huge injections received so far) following the tests.

10.22am BST

Strong pound hits WPP and Bunzl

As if all these grey swans weren’t bad enough, WPP is also suffering from the strong pound.

The ad company said its revenues had been “ravaged” by the strength of sterling (which meant that overseas revenues were worth less when converted into pounds).

Bunzl, the distribution and outsourcing group, had a similar tale for the City this morning, saying the strong pound has “significantly decreased” its growth.

10.19am BST

10.14am BST

Sorry, I should have explained what Sorrell means by saying Scottish independence and Britain’s potential exit from the EU are ‘Grey Swan’ risks.

He’s harking back to Nassim Taleb’s “Black Swan” theory, which argued that financial markets (and the rest of us) fail to predict certain events because they fall outside previous experience so can’t be anticipated, even though they have seismic consequences.

A Grey Swan, in Sorrell’s terms, is a “known unknowns” -- an event that can be predicted, but whose impact is unclear.

Other Grey Swans include the weak eurozone economy, and the prospect of a ‘hard landing’ in China, or the wider developing economies.

Updated at 10.14am BST

9.35am BST

Martin Sorrell has also voiced his concerns about Scottish independence to the BBC:

Updated at 9.52am BST

9.33am BST

Sorrell: Scottish independence and Brexit are grey swan threats

Sir Martin Sorrell has also warned that the prospects of Scotland voting for independence, and Britain leaving the European Union, could both threaten the UK economy.

The head of advertising giant WPP told Reuters this morning that these issues are “grey swans” that could disrupt the recovery.

TNS, which is WPP’s polling arm, currently has the “No to independence” vote leading, but the number of ‘don’t knows’ is larger than the gap that the Yes side needs to scale.

And with Alex Salmond winning last night’s debate with Alistair Darling, the vote could still be wide open.

Sorrell explains:

There is all to play for as we go into the election.

Obviously it does increase uncertainty in the UK, it’s not good.

[the question of] “What is our position in relation to the European market, to the EU?” is an added uncertainty.

Those fears around Brexit will escalate as we mover closer to 2017 when the in/out referendum will take place (assuming the Conservatives form the next government), he added.

The debates will start with regard to “our role, or non-role”, in Europe closer to that time, Sorrell says.

Updated at 11.54am BST

9.08am BST

9.01am BST

WPP boss: Russia has replaced eurozone as the main risk

Russia has replaced the eurozone as the major worry facing the global economy, WPP boss Sir Martin Sorrell has warned.

Sorrell says he met with fellow business leaders in Geneva, and saw the geopolitics has raced up the agenda.

In an interview with Reuters (online here), Sorrell explained:

The eurozone was the big topic of conversation and concern this time last year.

This year it’s been replaced by the Middle East, and in particular by Russia and the impact of sanctions.

Those sanctions will start to bite in the months ahead, and could have a knock-on effect on hurt businesses across Europe.

The slowest growing region for WPP this year is Western Continental Europe, Sorrell says. France, Italy and Spain all remain quite fragile.

And on France....

Sorrell also says that the latest French political crisis show the “tremendous political tensions” between people who want more austerity and cost controls and those who want Keynesian stimulus.

France is not complying with what Brussels and Mario Draghi want in terms of budget control, Sorrell concludes, contrasting it with Britain, where the chancellor has done a “great job” and “the economy is growing at 4%”.

Updated at 9.08am BST

8.36am BST

8.28am BST

European government bonds are also strengthening in value this morning, driven by the prospect of an ECB QE programme.

Yesterday’s fall in business confidence in Germany is also pushing investors into safe-haven assets such as German bunds.

The yield, or interest rate, on German 10-year bunds has fallen to just 0.932% today.

Italian 10-year bond yields have dropped by 5 basis points, from 2.45% to 2.4%, and Spanish yields are down a chunky 7 basis points to 2.19%.

Michael Hewson of CMC Markets explains how Mario Draghi’s speech on Friday night is making waves.

Draghi’s speech has been construed as a significant departure from the usual rhetoric usually used by ECB heads, in that he has ventured into areas normally reserved for politicians, and is particularly notable at a time when the political temperature in Europe looks set to rise further in the wake of the collapse of the French government, which is under increasing pressure from Brussels and Berlin to get its spending under control.

Despite these political concerns and yet another poor German IFO business confidence survey yesterday European stock markets rose sharply on Monday as markets looked to price in the prospect of further policy easing by the ECB in an attempt to try and boost economic growth in the euro area.

8.14am BST

European market open

The London stock market is open after the long weekend, and staging a small rally.

Mario Draghi’s pledge to use “all available instruments” to help the eurozone is cheering the City.

The FTSE 100 rose 39 points, or 0.55%, at the start of trading to 6815.

European markets are dipping a little, though, after yesterday’s big rally.

8.05am BST

Reuters: French PM to unveil pro-reform cabinet

Reuters has a good piece on the French political crisis, sparked by the dismissal of economy minister (and austerity critic) Arnaud Montebourg:

France’s prime minister will scramble to put together a new pro-reform government on Tuesday, a day after the surprise eviction of rebel ministers who had opposed budgetary rigor.

Manuel Valls will seek as wide a basis as possible for his second cabinet in five months ahead of tough negotiations at home and with EU peers on France’s 2015 budget and he is expected to try to poach politicians from other parties.

Economists reckon Valls’ new administration could benefit from a tighter focus on economic plans; at a time when France is struggling to grow, and missing the budget targets agreed with Brussels.

An unrepentant Montebourg, though, repeated his call for a new plan last night, telling reporters:

The whole world is begging us to put an end to these absurd austerity policies which are burying the euro zone deeper and deeper in recession and which will soon end up with deflation.

7.56am BST

7.44am BST

London stock market to play catch-up

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the financial markets, the economy, the eurozone and business.

The London stock market is expected to rise this morning as investors respond to the prospect of fresh stimulus measures from the European Central Bank to help the struggling eurozone economy and fight deflation.

City traders meandering back to their desks after a soggy bank holiday missed yesterday’s strong rally in other European markets, which saw the French CAC surge over 2%.

They’re likely to push the FTSE 100 up by around 35 points, back over the 6,800 mark.

Mario Draghi’s speech last Friday does appear to be another significant moment in the crisis. The ECB chief’s pledge to use “all available instruments” is seen as a prelude to a quantitative easing programme (QE) from Europe’s central bank.

This prospect rippled as far as Wall Street, helping to push pushed the S&P 500 index over the 2000 point mark for the first time ever last night.

And the euro is hovering near its lowest level in a year, at $1.32 to the dollar.

Stan Shamu of IG explains:

Driving sentiment across the globe at the moment are bets we will see further stimulus from some of the major central banks.

In European trade [yesterday] investors responded to Mario Draghi’s comments from the weekend in an overwhelmingly positive way and euro weakness helped to give equities an extra kicker.

A QE programme (buying assets with newly minted money) wouldn’t actually drag the eurozone out of its low-growth, low-inflation torpor on its own, mind you.

And that’s why Mario Draghi also called for more growth-friendly fiscal policies last Friday; a hot topic right now in France, where the government resigned yesterday as a row over its austerity programme erupted.

France thrown into political turmoil after government dissolved

President Holland has ordered Prime Minister Manuel Valls to form a new cabinet “consistent with the direction set for the country”. We should get details later today.

Investors will also be watching the talks between Ukrainian president Petro Poroshenko and Russia’s Vladimir Putin, at a summit in Minsk today.

Otherwise, it’s a fairly quiet day, until a splurge of US economic data this afternoon – including durable goods sales at 1.30pm, and consumer confidence survey at 3pm.

Updated at 7.47am BST

On an unadjusted basis, prices at these 20 areas rose by 1%. Nationally, prices fell by 0.1% on a seasonally adjusted basis. The monthly National Index rose 0.9% in June. While all 20 cities saw higher home prices over the last 12 months, all experienced slower gains. In San Francisco, the pace of price increases halved since late last summer. The Sun Belt cities – Las Vegas, Phoenix, Miami and Tampa – all remain a third or more below their peak prices set almost a decade ago.” In contrast, the average UK house price is now above its pre-crisis peak. Blitzer warns that the prospect of rising US interest rates will weigh on the market: “Bargain basement mortgage rates won’t continue forever; recent improvements in the labor markets and comments from Fed chair Janet Yellen and others hint that interest rates could rise as soon as the first quarter of 2015. Rising mortgage rates won’t send housing into a tailspin, but will further dampen price gains.” The record-breaking durable goods survey also shows a 318% spike in demand for civilian planes. So why did aircraft orders shoot up so much last month? Well, as fastFT points out, July was the month of the Farnborough Airshow. The diplomatic spat between Russia and the UK, which saw its delegation recalled home, dominated attention. But behind the scenes, US aerospace firms must have been racking up the orders. Just in: orders for US durable goods have soared by a record amount, and it’s all thanks to increased demand for aircraft. Durable goods orders surged by 22.6% in July, smashing expectations of a 7.5% rise. Strip out transportation orders, though, and orders for durable goods (items designed to last at least three years) fell by 0.8%. June’s durable goods report has been revised higher, to +2.7% from +0.7% originally. A handy comparison: The Burger King deal values Tim Hortons at C$12.5bn, or almost £7bn, btw. It’s official: US fast food chain Burger King is merging with Canadian coffee and doughnut chain Tim Hortons. The deal will create the world’s third-largest “quick service” restaurant company, more than 18,000 restaurants turning over a whopping $23bn of sales. The two companies will maintain the current “global homes” in Oakville and Miami respectively once the deal goes though. The merger is controversial, though -- it could allow Burger King cut its tax bills by shifting its tax domicile to Canada, where corporation tax is lower. Burger King’s majority owners, 3G Capital, have agreed to pay $94.05 Canadian dollars per share for Tim Hortons, in cash and shares. Tim Hortons shares were worth around C$67 last week, before news of a possible deal broke. Warren Buffett has a part to play in the deal too -- his Berkshire Hathaway investment group is providing $3bn of financing. And Tim Hortons has reassured staff that there will be no changes to ‘restaurant level’ employment. There’s a flurry of new data on the UK housing market today. First up, the number of new mortgages approved by lenders dipped last month to 42,792, below the recent average. But the average loan value increased, from £163,800 in June to £167,600 in July - as prices kept rising. More here: Small dip in July mortgage approvals offset by increase in average value Secondly, estate agent Savills has revised up its forecasts for price growth. It now expects average annual UK house price growth of 9.5% this year, ahead of the 6.5% originally forecast. Savills also acknowledged that London’s property boom has taken it by surprise. It originally expected price growth of 8.5% this year - now upgraded to 15%. But over the next five years, average UK prices should slightly outpace the capital, it reckons, growing by 25%: Ireland’s unemployment rate has hit its lowest level since the financial crisis struck the Celtic Tiger, as more people find work, and more people left the labour force altogether. The jobless rate across the Republic fell to 11.5% in the April-June quarter, the Central Statistics Office reported. Employment is up by 1.7% over the last year, with 31,600 more people finding work. And the number of unemployed people dropped by 46,200, taking the total to 254,500. The total labour force has contracted too, by 14,500. Another chart from the OECD, showing how the UK and US economies outpaced the major economies in the last quarter: Growth has picked up in the world’s major developed economies, with the UK and US making up for the weakness of Japan and the eurozone. That’s according to a new report from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development reports. It says GDP across the 33 countries who make up the OECD area rose by 0.4% in April-June, up from 0.2% in January-March. There was “a wide spectrum of patterns across countries”, though. Real quarterly growth in the US surged by 1%, followed by Britain with 0.8%. Japan contracted by 1.7% as a new sales tax hit spending, Germany shrank by 0.2% and France was flat. South Africa’s economy has returned to growth, avoiding a new recession, but not expanding as fast as hoped. Statistics South Africa reports that the country’s GDP rose by 0.6% in the second quarter of 2014, reversing the 0.6% contraction recorded in January-March. Economists had predicted growth of 0.9%. Our correspondent Helena Smith reports from Athens: It’s a problem that has mirrored Greece’s seemingly never ending debt crisis: the issue of non performing loans. With some 35% of all lender loans no longer being serviced, the country’s central bank reckons that an estimated €75bn in total is currently owed to banks, among the largest amounts in global financial history and for a nation off just over 11 million proportionately by far the largest in the EU. “It’s the biggest headache for our banking system and a major drain on our ability to provide credit,” said one banker requesting anonymity. “The new code has been a priority over the summer.” Ahead of EU-wide stress tests in October, Greece’s central bank has now devised a new code (yet to be fine-tuned) that reportedly allows ‘compromise solutions’ to be found for lenders and debtors. Rubber-stamped by the Committee of Credit and Insurance Matters on Monday the code, say insiders, foresees “haircuts” being extended to loans, revisions on interest repayments, the conversion of mortgages into rental contracts and the voluntary return of properties to banks (a way for lenders not to be seen to be forcibly requisitioning assets). Foreclosures will be activated if mortgage borrowers are seen to be deliberately uncooperative - with the collapse of property prices many Greeks, hit by austerity measures, simply gave up on repayments as the crisis intensified. “Such steps have been taken in other [EU] countries to handle non performing loans. Frankly we’ve dragged our feet. It’s in no one’s interest to have this hanging,” said the banker. “All round this should be a relief.” Former finance minister Yannis Stournaras who assumed the post of governor of the bank of Greece earlier this summer, is believed to be pushing hard for the code of ethics to be applied before the stress tests later this year. Bankers have not hidden their concerns that Greek lenders may need big capital injections to survive (despite huge injections received so far) following the tests. As if all these grey swans weren’t bad enough, WPP is also suffering from the strong pound. The ad company said its revenues had been “ravaged” by the strength of sterling (which meant that overseas revenues were worth less when converted into pounds). Bunzl, the distribution and outsourcing group, had a similar tale for the City this morning, saying the strong pound has “significantly decreased” its growth. Sorry, I should have explained what Sorrell means by saying Scottish independence and Britain’s potential exit from the EU are ‘Grey Swan’ risks. He’s harking back to Nassim Taleb’s “Black Swan” theory, which argued that financial markets (and the rest of us) fail to predict certain events because they fall outside previous experience so can’t be anticipated, even though they have seismic consequences. A Grey Swan, in Sorrell’s terms, is a “known unknowns” -- an event that can be predicted, but whose impact is unclear. Other Grey Swans include the weak eurozone economy, and the prospect of a ‘hard landing’ in China, or the wider developing economies. Martin Sorrell has also voiced his concerns about Scottish independence to the BBC: Sir Martin Sorrell has also warned that the prospects of Scotland voting for independence, and Britain leaving the European Union, could both threaten the UK economy. The head of advertising giant WPP told Reuters this morning that these issues are “grey swans” that could disrupt the recovery. TNS, which is WPP’s polling arm, currently has the “No to independence” vote leading, but the number of ‘don’t knows’ is larger than the gap that the Yes side needs to scale. And with Alex Salmond winning last night’s debate with Alistair Darling, the vote could still be wide open. Sorrell explains: There is all to play for as we go into the election. France is not complying with what Brussels and Mario Draghi want in terms of budget control, Sorrell concludes, contrasting it with Britain, where the chancellor has done a “great job” and “the economy is growing at 4%”. European government bonds are also strengthening in value this morning, driven by the prospect of an ECB QE programme. Yesterday’s fall in business confidence in Germany is also pushing investors into safe-haven assets such as German bunds. The yield, or interest rate, on German 10-year bunds has fallen to just 0.932% today. Italian 10-year bond yields have dropped by 5 basis points, from 2.45% to 2.4%, and Spanish yields are down a chunky 7 basis points to 2.19%. Michael Hewson of CMC Markets explains how Mario Draghi’s speech on Friday night is making waves. Draghi’s speech has been construed as a significant departure from the usual rhetoric usually used by ECB heads, in that he has ventured into areas normally reserved for politicians, and is particularly notable at a time when the political temperature in Europe looks set to rise further in the wake of the collapse of the French government, which is under increasing pressure from Brussels and Berlin to get its spending under control. Despite these political concerns and yet another poor German IFO business confidence survey yesterday European stock markets rose sharply on Monday as markets looked to price in the prospect of further policy easing by the ECB in an attempt to try and boost economic growth in the euro area. The London stock market is open after the long weekend, and staging a small rally. Mario Draghi’s pledge to use “all available instruments” to help the eurozone is cheering the City. The FTSE 100 rose 39 points, or 0.55%, at the start of trading to 6815. European markets are dipping a little, though, after yesterday’s big rally. Reuters has a good piece on the French political crisis, sparked by the dismissal of economy minister (and austerity critic) Arnaud Montebourg: France’s prime minister will scramble to put together a new pro-reform government on Tuesday, a day after the surprise eviction of rebel ministers who had opposed budgetary rigor. Manuel Valls will seek as wide a basis as possible for his second cabinet in five months ahead of tough negotiations at home and with EU peers on France’s 2015 budget and he is expected to try to poach politicians from other parties. Economists reckon Valls’ new administration could benefit from a tighter focus on economic plans; at a time when France is struggling to grow, and missing the budget targets agreed with Brussels. An unrepentant Montebourg, though, repeated his call for a new plan last night, telling reporters: The whole world is begging us to put an end to these absurd austerity policies which are burying the euro zone deeper and deeper in recession and which will soon end up with deflation. City traders meandering back to their desks after a soggy bank holiday missed yesterday’s strong rally in other European markets, which saw the French CAC surge over 2%. They’re likely to push the FTSE 100 up by around 35 points, back over the 6,800 mark. Mario Draghi’s speech last Friday does appear to be another significant moment in the crisis. The ECB chief’s pledge to use “all available instruments” is seen as a prelude to a quantitative easing programme (QE) from Europe’s central bank. This prospect rippled as far as Wall Street, helping to push pushed the S&P 500 index over the 2000 point mark for the first time ever last night. And the euro is hovering near its lowest level in a year, at $1.32 to the dollar. Stan Shamu of IG explains: Driving sentiment across the globe at the moment are bets we will see further stimulus from some of the major central banks. In European trade [yesterday] investors responded to Mario Draghi’s comments from the weekend in an overwhelmingly positive way and euro weakness helped to give equities an extra kicker. A QE programme (buying assets with newly minted money) wouldn’t actually drag the eurozone out of its low-growth, low-inflation torpor on its own, mind you. And that’s why Mario Draghi also called for more growth-friendly fiscal policies last Friday; a hot topic right now in France, where the government resigned yesterday as a row over its austerity programme erupted. France thrown into political turmoil after government dissolved President Holland has ordered Prime Minister Manuel Valls to form a new cabinet “consistent with the direction set for the country”. We should get details later today. Investors will also be watching the talks between Ukrainian president Petro Poroshenko and Russia’s Vladimir Putin, at a summit in Minsk today. Otherwise, it’s a fairly quiet day, until a splurge of US economic data this afternoon – including durable goods sales at 1.30pm, and consumer confidence survey at 3pm.

webTitle: FTSE 100 hits seven week high on Draghi QE hints

fields.standfirst: Investors hope for more cheap central bank money, as global tensions ease
fields.body:
Super Mario helped supercharge UK shares to their highest level for seven weeks as the London market caught up with Monday's gains elsewhere after the August Bank holiday.

Investors were enthused by Fridays' comments from ECB boss Mario Draghi at the Jackson Hole central bank meeting in the US, when he hinted that stimulus measures such as quantitative easing could be on the cards to boost the struggling eurozone economy. The weekend political rift in France over austerity only served to reinforce the idea that action probably needed to be taken.

On top of that, there was a strong start in the US after consumer confidence hit its highest level since October 2007 and durable goods sales surged, albeit helped by big aircraft orders for Boeing at the Farnborough air show in July.

Hopes of easing tensions in Ukraine and Russia, as well as in Gaza, also helped sentiment, as did news of the proposed $11.4bn takeover of Canada's Tim Hortons by America's Burger King.

So the FTSE 100 finished at its highest level since 7 July, up 47.51 points to 6822.76, although share volumes were still stuck in the summer lull.

Banks were boosted by the talk of possible QE from the ECB, with Barclays 2.45p better at 225.25p. Jasper Lawler, market analyst at CMC Markets UK, said:

While the UK would not directly benefit from Eurozone QE since it does not use the euro; London is the financial capital of Europe and there's a good chance some of the easy money would slosh across the Channel. Should the policy be enacted with the UK economy growing, it could be enough for the FTSE 100 to make new all-time highs above 6,950.

Airline shares were helped by signs the Icelandic volcano alert was easing, with British Airways owner International Airlines Group up 12.1p at 358.1p.

RSA Insurance rose 6.9p to 444p as Bank of America/Merrill Lynch moved its rating from neutral to buy. Merrill said:

Management actions regarding asset disposals, announced cost saves,further examination of larger businesses, enhanced disclosures, portfolio trimming and balance sheet clean-up shows no stone is being left unturned by the chief executive, Stephen Hester. We expect the group to beat the upper-end of its return on tangible equity target (12-15%) excluding restructuring charges as early as 2016. We forecast RSA will exceed its targeted capital metric (35%-45% total net asset value: premium) by 2015 and therefore introduce a special dividend per share. We increase our price target by 5% to 550p, forecast 28% total shareholder return and upgrade to buy.

AstraZeneca added 49.5p to 4467.5p as thwarted predator Pfizer could make a new approach - but only in the unlikely event of agreement from the AstraZeneca board. Pharmaceutical shares were also buoyed by Roche's deal to buy US biotech business InterMune for $8.3bn.

Bunzl climbed 9p to £16.39 as the business supplies company reported a 5% rise in six month profits to £176.6m despite revenues falling because of the strength of the pound.

Half year profits at advertising giant WPP was also hit by the sterling move, but its shares ended 17p higher at £12.44 as the company stuck to its growth targets for the year.

Lower down the market, Regus was another victim of the pound, with its shares down 17.5p to 179p after pretax profits fell slightly to £31m. The office provider said it would open at least 450 business centres this year but analysts were concerned this would add to costs, increase debts and depress earnings in the short term.

Data centre business Telecity lost 45.5p to 716p as it announced chief executive Michael Tobin would step down.

Elsewhere Antofagasta fell 9.5p to 798.5p after the Chilean copper miner said first half profits had dropped 11.5% to a lower than expected $1.13bn, hit by higher production costs and lower metal prices.

Oil and gas services company Petrofac dipped 3p to £11.23 as it reported a slump in first half profit from $243m to $136m, hit by various project delays.

Finally Asos added 168p or 7.6% to £23.48 on vague speculation of interest in the online fashion retailer. Weekend reports suggested Asos could face increased competition from Next, but traders ignored that and pointed to talk that the likes of eBay could be looking at the business, with a price of up to £50 a share mentioned.

fields.body:
My best friend, Beryl Foote, who has died after a stroke, aged 67, was probably the first woman quantity surveyor in the British building industry. Many images of Beryl come to mind. Almost invisible behind vast pads in hockey goal while still wearing her glasses. With hard hat and steely glare in place to face down the toughest sub-contractor on the biggest construction site. Climbing effortlessly through steep bluebell woods pointing out every tiny plant and naming every bird's song.

After shaky grades stopped her studying mathematics at Reading University, she dropped out of an electrical engineering degree at Warwick to become a pupil quantity surveyor in 1966 to John Laing. Thus began nearly 50 years in what she called "a bastion of male supremacy", working all over the south of England on both big and small commercial and domestic sites, transferring from the John Laing Group to George Wimpey. She was seen as a role model, was still working when she died and contributed to a case study of women in industry. She was gratified when the occasional woman began to appear on site, but lamented that they were so few.

Beryl lived alone, latterly in Basingstoke, Hampshire, and her great passion was solitary walking, especially in the New Forest and on the south coast. At work she had been a pioneer of the use of computers in the building industry and on her walks she took the latest gadgets; a state-of-the-art camera and a personal GPS system. She also loved her cars, invariably changed every two years and driven deftly with total understanding of what went on under the bonnet.

She loved nature, but was equally able to see the needs of progress, and of people, if a great crested newt held up her latest building assignment. As her company's liaison contact with English Nature (now Natural England), she was happy to provide badgers, in a development near Farnham, with corridors of scaffolding planks and fences, and daily supplies of nuts.

Beryl was brought up in Shaftesbury, Dorset, daughter of Kathleen and Norman. Her father, nicknamed Footy, was the local optician. Beryl was deputy head girl at Shaftesbury high school. She attributed to her father her determination, and she liked an argument, but these invariably ended with smiles because the absurdity of many of modern life's frustrations ultimately amused her.

webTitle: Circle Oil jumps by a quarter after Tunisia update

fields.standfirst: Company says discovery could mean recoverable reserves of around 100m barrels of oil
fields.body:
Circle Oil, the Middle East and African focused group, has jumped by a quarter following a positive update on its drilling off Tunisia.

The company said the EMD-1 well, which began drilling in June, had confirmed the existence of a working petroleum system in the area, although deteriorating conditions ultimately led to a suspension of the well. It said the most likely recoverable resources discovered from the well were approximately 100m barrels of oil. Chief executive Chris Green said:

We are extremely pleased to add this potential large discovery to our portfolio in Tunisia. It is unfortunate that the hole conditions became untenable so quickly and we were unable to conduct a full log evaluation of the hydrocarbon column in the well. Nevertheless we intend to take our appraisal effort forward on the Mahdia permit as quickly as possible.

The company has been given a six month extension to the permit to January 2015.

The news has lifted Circle's shares by 25%, up 4.5p to 22.25p, and analyst Brian Gallagher at Investec said:

After a longer than anticipated drill, Circle has announced that the EMD-1 located offshore Tunisia has encountered hydrocarbons shows. Pending appraisal, this result is a significant step forward for Circle.
A discovery of this size...would potentially attract new partners to the basin and de-risks the five existing prospects already mapped on the block. We increase our risked exploration net asset value by 20p and now set our price target at 70p [from 50p].

webTitle: FTSE gains ground but Antofagasta and Petrofac fall on updates

fields.standfirst: UK markets play catch up with Europe after holiday as Draghi comments support shares
fields.body:
Leading shares in London have moved higher as the UK market plays catch up, as it missed out on Monday's gains elsewhere due to the (wet) Bank Holiday.

webTitle: Stagecoach earnings rise after bus and train contract wins

fields.standfirst: Stagecoach and partner Virgin Trains won the right to run the west coast mainline service, a deal expected to triple their profits
fields.body:
Stagecoach has reported a robust increase in earnings after winning a series of contracts to run London buses and an extension to its deal to operate the west coast mainline train service.

Stagecoach and its joint venture partner Virgin Trains were recently awarded a revised deal to run the west coast mainline between London and Scotland until 2017 – an agreement that is expected to triple their profits from the line.

Although it is still too early to judge the success of the franchise extension, which began on 22 June, Stagecoach said business had been strong.

It reported a 5% increase in quarterly revenues for its entire UK rail business on last year.

The Perth-based transport group also benefited from winning two new bus contracts in London, adding to the services it runs in the south-east of the capital. London bus revenues were up 14%, although the company said earnings were lower than expected because of traffic disruption caused by roadworks.

Stagecoach is one of the largest bus companies in the UK and earnings from its fleet of 8,100 regional buses and coaches, which account for more than a quarter of its revenue, were up 4%.

The group, which runs no-frills coach service Megabus and Sheffield's super tram, reported that passenger numbers were up 0.9% over the quarter, bucking the trend of declining bus use outside London.

Stagecoach has also teamed up with Virgin to bid for the east coast franchise, which is expected to be announced in November.

The London-to-Edinburgh route has been in public ownership since 2009, but is due to make a controversial return to private hands early next year.

Stagecoach is also one of three shortlisted bidders for the TransPennine Express rail franchise along with FirstGroup and Keolis, which currently run the service in a joint venture.

webTitle: Number of houses worth £1m or more rises by 49%, latest figures show

fields.bodyText: The number of homes across Britain valued at £1m or more has increased by 49% over the past year, according to figures published on Tuesday. Living in a road of £1m-plus homes is no longer a badge of exclusivity. The property website Zoopla, which compiled the data, found that there are 3,744 streets in London where the price of homes is on average higher than £1m, and 10,613 across the country. It estimated that 484,081 households can now claim to be property millionaires. The true price of entry into the property big league is now at least £10m, with estate agents preferring billionaires rather than buyers commanding only six zeroes. Zoopla found 12 streets, all in the capital, where house prices averaged more than £10m. Kensington Palace Gardens finished top of the list. Britain's most expensive street is made up of vast detached palaces that sell on average for £42.7m – up 12% over the last year and 161 times the average UK home price – and whose super-elite residents include Chelsea football club owner Roman Abramovich and steel magnate Lakshmi Mittal. A somewhat worn-out five-bed apartment on a 1960s block in the road, which even the agents admit is "in need of modernisation", is on the market for £23.5m. It does, however, include a "chauffeur's room". The next most expensive street in Britain is the Boltons, also in Kensington, where average prices are £26.6m. This summer, one owner on the street, Paul Burdell, put his home on the market inviting buyers to pay £20.5m and then knock it down. The multimillionaire debt collector, whose firm specialises in tracking down hard-up families who owe money to banks and credit card companies, won a lengthy battle against neighbours, including footballer Frank Lampard, for permission to demolish his home and rebuild it with three storeys underground, including a swimming pool, gym and cinema, but now wants to sell. Britain's third most expensive street, Grosvenor Crescent, is a busy road running off Hyde Park Corner, where properties change hands for an average of £22.3m. But even that doesn't get you your own front door or garden. Agents recently marketed a three-bed flat on the crescent for £18m, while a two-bed flat was listed for rental last year at £7,150 a month. For that, tenants have to make do with a lounge-cum-diner and a second bedroom that is just 8ft x 11ft. Outside London, the most expensive street in Britain is Sunninghill Road in Surrey, where the average home is currently worth £5.6m. The two most expensive towns outside London are both in Surrey, with average house prices in Virginia Water at £1.2m and in Cobham at a shade over £1m.
